Emacs is great, but the version here cannot execute things on the host system except for through flatpak-spawn. This means that any third party package you install that relies on external binaries will not work out of the box.
summary: Limited host system access limits usability

description:
You're probably already familiar with what Emacs is and what it can do, so allow me to, so allow me to present the core philosophy of the program; be introspectable and be extensible.

What this means is that everything you do in Emacs, every keybinding, every button action is bound to a function, which you can then read the source code of, modify and re-evaluate.

For programmers, this is nirvana. Non-programmers also benefit in the form of excellent extensions that are written for Emacs that are easily install-able via the built-in package manager.
summary: One of the best software packages ever written

description: Co co Cool co co Cool
summary: Its like using vim over emacs ~~ Richard Hendricks

description:
This installs an older version of emacs and the package can't be removed automatically. To clean up requires a lot of digging, what a mess. This should be removed from the software store.

Better off to use the command line :
snap info emacs
summary: Easier to install this one manually

description: I use emacs for a long time now, it became a great tool (lots of packages) for my development and notes workflow. If you have time to spend for learning emacs, give it a try.

If I could choose one program to bring with me to a desserted island, it would be Emacs. There is nothing you can't do here.

The learning curve for brand new users are way smaller than for something like VIM, but it's more complicated than VSCode. Frameworks like Doom Emacs however brings the complexity down to the same level of VSCode.

If you want an editor that works regardless of language or workflow, this is for you. If you want a platform/program/operatingsystem where everything is as integrated as Mac OS, this editor is for you.
summary: simply the single greatest program of all time

description: It's versatile, fast and good in every sense to be honest
summary: The best text editor and IDE

Has endless possibilities. Yes takes time to learn but totally worth it.

What is emacs? An ancient relic from a bygone era. I'd expect someone to throw the "I find your lack of faith disturbing" line at me at this point, but no emacs user is young enough to have enjoyed star wars so I won't hold my breath. Whenever someone mentions emacs I smell this old people stench for a moment.

Use emacs if you interact with your mainframe via a dumb terminal through serial. Use Vim if your "micro" is made after 1980.
...The Great Battle of Days Gone By. Emacs won the days, and history tells its story to this day. Long live Emacs!

description: I started using emacs in 1993. I have written all my theses (LaTeX) and all my code with it since then on many different UNIX-like platforms. It has never let me down and often surprised me with its useful features and the absence of bugs.

I've logged in thousands of multiplex tmux terminals on IBM mainframes and linux machines with vi/vim (Dvorak/60%) as my ultimate weapon as I weave sh scripts and killing daemons. Now, as a C++/Java Spring/Android developer using Intellij IDE, i sensed that vi/vim is no longer sufficient. Ten years, ago I heard of Emacs as like an operating system. Today, is my first day using Emacs for a change, to explore the legend and the power that lurks beneath
Great and powerfull text editor, which can be IDE, file manager, browser or whatever you want. Spent some time to set it up, and then it will help you a lot, so you can be more productive!
It's a whole universe, not just a text editor. Has a steep learning curve but can make you more efficient once you learn enough.
summary: Oldest open-source project in the world

El mejor editor que he usado en mi vida.

Llevo más de quince años usando emacs y me parece fantástico. La introducción en esta nueva versión (27.1) de pestañas me ha ido de perlas. Ahora puedo prescindir de elscreen. La configuración de las pestañas se guarda y se recupera entre sesiones para todas y cada uno de los frames que tengo abiertos.

Esta configuración con múltiples frames, con múltiples pestañas cada uno de ellos y con múltiples ventanas en cada pestaña no la he encontrado en ningún otro editor, ni atom, ni sublime, ni vim ni vscode, y la considero IMPRESCINDIBLE.

Es mi editor preferido para hacer programas de Fortran, en lenguaje c y en el que estoy tratando de aprender, Java. La diferencia fuendamental tratandose de Java es que con eclipse (que como sus creadores dicen: "sirve para todo y para nada") se obtiene una especie de plantilla o modelo que el programador tiene que llenar con las instrucciones de su lenguaje. Sin embargo, emacs te da la pantalla del editor en blanco pero tiene la gran ventaja de que cuando la persona que escribe una palabra reservada del lenguaje Java la escribe en color violeta y esto le indica al programador que la está escribiendo correctamente además de que el nombre del los métodos es escrito en color azul y el de las variables que escribe el programador en color verde siendo el tipo de variable (int, double, float, etc) escrito en color amarillo; estas cosas son muy útiles al momento de hacer programas. Además, después de escrito el programa con el editor emacs este puede ser compilado y los mensajes o diagnosticos de error son mejores en Linux.

Emacs demande du temps pour être utilisé à sa pleine mesure, mais l'effort est récompensé par une hausse de la productivité et un plaisir d'utilisation. Convient aux développeur, aux chefs de projets, aux enseignants, aux managers, ...
Emacs est comme la course à pieds; dur au début mais qui devient rapidement un plaisir nécessaire.
Très bon logiciel rien à dire.
